conclusion: Two harmonic transverse waves propagate along the positive and negative directions of the x-axis, respectively. The wave sources are located at x=-0.2m and x=1.2m, with both waves having a wave speed of 0.4m/s and an amplitude of 2m.

The figure shows the images of the two waves at time t=0. At this moment, the particles P and Q at the equilibrium positions x=0.2m and x=0.8m in the medium just begin to vibrate. The equilibrium position of particle M is located at x=0.5m.
To determine the time at which the two waves meet, we need to analyze the propagation of the waves from their sources and calculate the time it takes for them to reach the point where they meet.
Wave 1 propagates from x = -0.2 m along the positive x-axis.
Wave 2 propagates from x = 1.2 m along the negative x-axis.

premise: Wave 1 propagates from x = -0.2 m along the positive x-axis. Wave 2 propagates from x = 1.2 m along the negative x-axis.
conclusion: The waves will meet at the midpoint between the two sources.

premise: The distance between the sources is 1.2 m - (-0.2 m) = 1.4 m.
conclusion: The midpoint is at x = 0.5 m.

premise: Wave 1 travels from x = -0.2 m to x = 0.5 m.
conclusion: Distance traveled by Wave 1 is 0.5 m - (-0.2 m) = 0.7 m.

premise: Wave 2 travels from x = 1.2 m to x = 0.5 m.
conclusion: Distance traveled by Wave 2 is 1.2 m - 0.5 m = 0.7 m.
Both waves have a speed of 0.4 m/s.

premise: Distance traveled by Wave 1 is 0.7 m. Speed of Wave 1 is 0.4 m/s.
conclusion: Time for Wave 1 to reach the meeting point is t1 = 0.7 m / 0.4 m/s = 1.75 s.

premise: Distance traveled by Wave 2 is 0.7 m. Speed of Wave 2 is 0.4 m/s.
conclusion: Time for Wave 2 to reach the meeting point is t2 = 0.7 m / 0.4 m/s = 1.75 s.

premise: Time for Wave 1 to reach the meeting point is t1 = 1.75 s. Time for Wave 2 to reach the meeting point is t2 = 1.75 s.
conclusion: Both waves take the same amount of time to reach the meeting point.
